The  Project  has  three  investment  components:  energy  efficiency

Sri  Lanka’s  power  sector  struggled  throughout  the  late  1980s, 
1990s,  and  early  2000s  to  meet  the  growing  demand  for 
electricity.  Electricity  is  expensive  and  subject  to  interruptions. 
About  20%  of  households  do  not  have  access  to  it.  The  Ceylon 
Electricity  Board  is  burdened  with  debt,  restricting  its  ability  to 
make  capital  investments  and  discouraging  private  investment. 
The  Government  is  fully  committed  to  addressing  these  issues 
and has developed a Ten-Year Development Framework (TYDF). 
Under  the  TYDF,  the  Government  has  developed  a  national 
energy  policy  and  strategies  (NEPS).  The  NEPS  provides  a 
comprehensive  road  map  for  the  sector.  It  includes  a  long-term 
investment program and specific policy and reform measures and 
aims  to  (i)  supply  electricity  to  86%  of  households  by  2010  and 
98% by 2016, and (ii) ensure electricity tariffs are competitive with 
those in other countries and sufficient for utilities to be viable. 
 
 
Under  the  NEPS,  the  Government  is  accelerating  its  long-term 
generation  expansion  plan  (LGEP) 
to  build  up  generation 
capacity,  primarily  with  bilateral  funding.  At  the  same  time,  it  is

conservation  through  demand-side  management  needs  to  be 
more actively tapped. 
 
The  share  of  thermal  power  in  the  power  generation  mix  has 
increased  dramatically  from  1%  in  1986  to  58%  in  2008  as  the 
entire  demand  growth  has  been  served  by  oil-fired  thermal 
generation.  This  poses  a  serious  threat  to  the  country’s  energy 
security  as  well  as  to  the  environment,  given  Sri  Lanka’s 
overdependence on imported fossil fuels. Coupled with fuel price 
increases and the delayed construction of new hydropower plants, 
generation costs have substantially increased. There is an urgent 
need  to  develop  clean  energy  and  indigenous  renewable  energy 
sources.   
 
To  achieve  the  electrification  target  under  the  TYDF,  particular 
attention  needs  to  be  paid  to  regions  with  serious  power 
shortages  and  many  unconnected  households,  including  conflict-
affected  areas.  The  transmission system  is  currently  too  weak  to 
meet  growing  demand  in  the  regions.  Despite  the  Government’s 
intensive  investment  program  to  expand  the  rural  distribution 
network,  many  poor  households  remain  unconnected  even  in 
areas connected to the grid because they cannot afford the initial 
cost of service connection.  
 
The Project will support the Government to address these issues 
through  investment  loans  and  grant  and  associated  technical 
assistance.   
 
The  Government  has  taken  measures  to  strengthen  governance 
and  rationalize  tariffs.  The  Sri  Lanka  Electricity  Act  has  been 
passed  by  Parliament  in  March  2009.  It  will  empower  the  Public 
Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) to regulate the power 
sector.  To  restore  the  financial  viability  of  the  sector,  the 
Government  has  restructured  the  debt  of  the  Ceylon  Electricity

The  energy  efficiency  improvement  component  will  enhance  the 
overall reliability of the power system to benefit households, small 
and  medium-sized  businesses,  and  public  services,  including,  in 
particular,  schools  and  hospitals.  It  will  bring  power  to  industrial 
districts  where  existing  industries  currently  relying  on  captive 
generators  will  be  able  to  improve  their  productivity.  New 
investments  will  also  be  encouraged  by  the  additional  availability 
of  power.  In  both  cases,  a  sharp  increase  in  labor  demand  is 
ultimately  expected  to  benefit the local population. The demand- 
side management part is expected to save energy equivalent to a 
thermal  power  plant  of  3.5  MW.  The  renewable  energy 
development  component   will   help   bring  200   MW   of   clean 
hydropower energy into the grid, thereby reducing CO2-equivalent 
emissions per year by about 0.5 million tons.

Lessons 

 
22. 
In 1998, the Government committed itself to carrying out sector reforms and embarked 
on  a  program  to  restructure  the  power  sector  by  unbundling  CEB  into  separate  functional 
companies  and  establishing  an  independent  regulator.  The  Government  introduced  the 
Electricity  Reform  Act,  2002  to  provide  a  legal  framework  for  the  program.  However,  the 
unbundling of CEB did not materialize because of opposition from within the ruling coalition and 
from  the  powerful  labor  unions.  As  the  act  was  designed  to  enable  PUCSL  to  start  regulation 
following the unbundling of CEB, regulatory reform has been at a standstill. As a result, in 2006 
ADB  terminated  the  program  loans  to  support  the  reform  program  as  the  second  tranche 
conditions were unlikely to be fulfilled.     
 
23. 
The  main  reason  the  previous  reform  program  did  not  succeed  was  that  a  CEB  trade 
union  backed  by  a  leftist  party  protested  against  the  reform.  Since  the  leftist  party  was  a 
member  of  the  ruling  coalition,  the  Government  made  a  political  choice  not  to  unbundle  CEB. 
Some members of the Government and CEB who believed that the most pressing need was to 
build  a  cheaper  base  load  capacity  rather  than  to  carry  out  reform  also  influenced  the 
Government  decision.  Some  stakeholders  also  perceived  the  reform  process  to  be  donor-
driven. 
 
24. 
Based  on  the  lessons  learned  from  the  previous  reform  attempt,  ADB  encouraged  the 
Government to conduct intensive consultations with stakeholders when preparing a fresh sector 
development program. The Government prepared the NEPS and had it approved by Parliament 
to  ensure  ownership  by  all  political  stakeholders.  The  Government  has  taken  a  pragmatic 
approach to this round of regulatory reform and as a result has faced less political resistance.  It 
left  CEB  vertically  integrated  and  delinked  regulatory  reform  from  the  restructuring  of  CEB.  It 
decided  to  introduce  the  Sri  Lanka  Electricity  Act,  designed  to  encourage  efficiency 
improvement  by  CEB  by  regulating  each  FBU.  Recognizing  these  policy  actions  as  a  strong 
indication of the Government’s commitment to reform, ADB resumed its support for the power 
sector  by  approving  a  TA  project6 in  December  2007  and  a  country  operations  business  plan 
which includes the current Project.  The Sri Lanka Electricity Act was passed by Parliament in 
March 2009 to complete the regulatory reform.

8. 
The  Government  established  the  Public  Utilities  Commission  of  Sri  Lanka  (PUCSL)  in 
2002  as  a  regulator  for  the  energy  and  water  sectors  under  the  PUCSL  Act,  2002.  However, 
although the act ensures the independent status of PUCSL staff, the final authority for issuing 
licenses  and  determining  electricity  tariffs  is  vested  in  the  Government  (PUCSL  has  been 
advising the Government on policy decisions, including setting tariffs). In order to transfer these 
powers to PUCSL and to empower it to regulate the sector fully, Parliament has passed the Sri 
Lanka  Electricity  Act  in  March  2009.  The  first  licenses  to  CEB,  LECO,  and  the  utilities  will  be 
issued within 6 months from its enactment.   
 
9. 
CEB  has  converted  its  generation,  transmission  and  distribution  operations  into  six 
functional  business  units  (FBUs),  one  for  generation,  one  for  transmission,  and  four  for 
distribution. Financial accounts have been segregated so that each FBU will operate as a profit 
center.  PUCSL  will  regulate  each  FBU  separately  and  issue  individual  licenses.  The  board  of 
CEB will delegate to the respective heads of the FBU all day-to-day management and the power 
to take all decisions to fulfill the obligations of the FBU under its license, including all financial 
powers to make capital and other investments, recruit personnel, and incur revenue expenses 
to the extent required to ensure the FBU achieves its revenue targets as approved by PUCSL. 
The board will also authorize the heads of FBUs to delegate some of the functions of the FBU to 
its officers. A memorandum of performance to be signed between the heads of FBUs and the 
board to ensure that FBU heads will (i) fulfill the license conditions; (ii) achieve the performance 
standards  set  by  the  regulator;  and  (iii)  have  both  administrative  and  financial  autonomy  to 
manage the FBU within the stipulations of the license.

Loss  Reduction.  CEB’s  transmission  and  distribution  losses  have  been  between  15% 
and 17% of net generation over the past two decades (although they increased to about 21% in 
2000,  because  of  the  excessive  number  of  connections  without  meters).  The  number  of 
connections without meters has now been reduced to a minimum. While the losses have now 
reverted to the pre-2000 levels, they are significantly above the optimal levels of about 12%. In 
2008,  the  transmission  and  distribution  loss  was  estimated  to  be  15.0%  of  net  generation. 
These  additional  losses  are  partly  technical  and  include  overheating  cables  and  transformers, 
because of the excessive current caused by the unplanned connection of new customers, and 
non-implementation of planned improvements to the network because of financial constraints. A 
smaller share of the losses is due to connections without meters, metering errors, and theft. The 
Government will accelerate improvements to those sections of the transmission and distribution 
network where losses are high, and replace and upgrade the network to reduce losses, which 
would also improve service quality in terms of voltage profile. The Government will also make a 
parallel  effort  to  upgrade  and  improve  the  meters  and  the  metering  system,  and  conduct 
surveillance  on  theft.  An  investment  of  $87  million  in  the  loss  reduction  program  is  planned, 
including  $64  million  for  the  medium-  and  low-voltage  technical  loss  reduction  program  and  
$23  million  for  the  nontechnical  loss  reduction  program.  By  these  measures,  the  Government 
plans to reduce overall losses to 12% by 2016. The Government also plans to pilot innovative 
outsourcing  projects  with  ADB  assistance,  particularly  for  nontechnical  loss  reductions  in  peri-

tax  and  other  payment  arrears  and  made  direct  payments  of  SLRs3.5  billion  to  the  Ceylon 
Petroleum  Corporation  on  behalf  of  CEB.  The  restructuring  of  CEB’s  long-term  debt  of

Pallekelle  the  connection  to  the  grid  will  increase  the  productivity  of  the  existing  factories  (which  have  been  relying  on 
generators)  and  will  boost  the  investments  in  new  factories.  In  both  cases  jobs  will  be  created.  In  addition  to  the  facilities 
made  available  to  small-scale  industries,  Medium-sized  and  large  industries  can  also  benefit  from  the  availability  of 
substations and spur medium voltage lines. This will open up opportunities for villages to sell ancillary services to industries. 
 
Finally, the Asian Development Fund (ADF) component will support CEB to provide connections to poor households in rural 
Sri Lanka. The pilot program will be implemented first in three of the poorest districts: Hambantota, Ratnapura, and the East. 
Households will be more productive, employment will be created, home garden cultivation will be increased through the use of 
domestic water pumps, and backyard farms and small cottage industries will benefit.  
 
This  component  is  expected  to  improve  the  living  standards  of  poor  households,  by  improving  health  conditions,  reducing 
expenditure  on  power  (on-grid  electricity  is  cheaper  and  more  reliable  than  kerosene),  increasing  their  productivity  and 
income, and increasing the number of hours children can study at night. 
 
Non-electrified households in Sri Lanka use kerosene oil for domestic lighting so electrification will lead to savings in the use 
of imported fuel.

Generally, Sri Lanka enjoys social indicators that are higher than those in other countries of similar economic status. It has a

Nonetheless, social development has been uneven throughout the country. In designing the ADF component (connection for 
the poor) selection was made at three different levels.  
 
Target Districts.  Based on poverty indicators, national policy on rural electrification, and ADB’s focus on Eastern Province, 
the  three  districts  of  Ampara,  Hambantota  and  Ratnapura  have  been  short-listed  for  the  initial  round  of  the  project.  Other

main grid electricity will apply here as well.
